channel.title: Just want to verify this theory about the com.ms packages
channel.description:
Well, so I went to deob a newer 612 client and got it to go through the deob process easily. But as soon as it deobed and I ran it through ZKM's renaming tool thing it shat bricks when it came across the com.ms packages, through help from popbob this was linked back to the old Microsoft JVM's J/Direct, so in theory if you got your hands on an MS JVM with J/Direct and included in the classpath it should work fine.
I am also assuming that this stuff is there for backwards compatibility with the MS JVM so once the client is deobed this can be removed and it wouldn't matter to anyone not running the MS JVM. It seems like to me all the J/Direct stuff is there for is for people using the MS JVM to be able to play in DX mode.
If I'm on the right track here tell me if I'm not feel free to call me an idiot but please hint me in the right direction. Also if I'm right and someone has a better solution please do share.

item.title: Just want to verify this theory about the com.ms packages
item.dc:creator: @_bool
item.description:
@_bool wrote:

[quote=“Speljohan, post:8, topic:347006”][quote author=(Anthony) link=topic=443383.msg3255820#msg3255820 date=1278099458]

Try it and find out.

Would be a lot easier if someone had the MS JVM with J/Direct(Apparently not all versions have it).
If you do or know any one who does please do share.

EDIT: i got msjvm and installed it but I can’t find any fucking deps like J/Direct…
EDIT: I got it but I think one of my transforms are broken cause ZKM throws an ArrayIndexOutOfBounds.
EDIT AGAIN: it seems that the ArrayIndexOutOfBounds is caused by having an old ZKM anyone have version 4.4.7+.
[/quote]Throw me a pm and i’ll upload latest version for you (i has a license)[/quote]
Ok, cool beans.

Read full topic

item.title: Just want to verify this theory about the com.ms packages
item.dc:creator: @_bool
item.description:
@_bool wrote:

Yeah that’s true but just examining some more classes it clearly calls the classes from J/Direct.
It’s DX wrappers, it’s user32 wrapper, etc.
I’m pretty sure on that one now I just want to know if there is a better solution than digging up the MS JVM and including J/Direct in the classpath.

Read full topic
item.source: Just want to verify this theory about the com.ms packages

item.title: Just want to verify this theory about the com.ms packages
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote="(Anthony), post:3, topic:347006"][quote author=Speljohan link=topic=443383.msg3255773#msg3255773 date=1278096075]
I haven’t looked, but my guess would be that the com.ms package has nothing to do with their old jvm whatsoever. It’s most likely just bindings for directx.
[/quote]
How would it be bindings for DirectX if it doesn’t even have them??
And it has bindings for DirectX already in the client jar in the package “jagdx” that’s why I assumed it’s something else.
Also I wouldn’t think MS would write DX bindings for Java cause they don’t support it and use their .NET crap.[/quote]Oh ok, no clue then.

Microsoft would most likely not write bindings, but who’s to stop someone else from doing it? The commonly used java opengl bindings weren’t written by sun (lwjgl, jogl)

Read full topic
item.source: Just want to verify this theory about the com.ms packages

item.title: Just want to verify this theory about the com.ms packages
item.dc:creator: @_bool
item.description:
@_bool wrote:

Speljohan:

I haven’t looked, but my guess would be that the com.ms package has nothing to do with their old jvm whatsoever. It’s most likely just bindings for directx.

How would it be bindings for DirectX if it doesn’t even have them??
And it has bindings for DirectX already in the client jar in the package “jagdx” that’s why I assumed it’s something else.
Also I wouldn’t think MS would write DX bindings for Java cause they don’t support it and use their .NET crap.
Also it calls classes specifically from J/Direct like com.ms.win32.User32 and com.ms.dll.Callback and it’s DX wrappers.

Read full topic
item.source: Just want to verify this theory about the com.ms packages
